blocks.text:
The length of arc $L$ can thus be found if the value of the integral on the R.H.S. can be evaluated.

In only a few cases is the evaluation of the integral simple; for most curves, an approximation is taken. This is justified in the form of an elliptic integral, this being treated later in the chapter; and hence the approximate rules are nearly always accurate.
To deal with a case of a very simple character:

blocks.description: An integral formula for calculating the length of an arc in a curve.

blocks.text:
In this case it is really a matter of determining the length of the line AB (Fig. 50):  
If $y = ax + b$, then we have:

blocks.description: The derivative of the function $y = ax + b$.

blocks.latex: L = \int_{A}^{B} \sqrt{1 + a^{2}} \cdot dx = \sqrt{1 + a^{2}} ( b - a),
blocks.description: The final equation provides the arc length between the points A and B.

blocks.text: For convenience, put the figure in Fig. 51.

blocks.caption: Figure 51: Length of arc in a parabola.
blocks.description: This figure illustrates the length of an arc segment in a parabolic shape, highlighting the points D and the span from base to apex.

blocks.text:
The arc length $L$ is given by  
$L = \frac{4}{3} D$  so that $D$ must be very large.
